Award.AwardTitle: Developing Consensus Guidelines for Tools and Processes that Assess Science Instructional Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent National Research Council (2013) publication, Monitoring Progress to Successful K-12 STEM Education (Monitoring Progress) identified fourteen indicators to assess the health of STEM education in US schools. This project is addressing the indicator that specifies the creation of a set of criteria to determine how well widely-used STEM instructional materials support the intent of national standards. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the creation of this criteria set. No other document exists that represents the collective knowledge and perspectives of science education leaders and clearly articulates the criteria to be used at a national level to determine how well science instructional materials embody the NGSS.

The project includes three phases: 1) a literature review of tools and processes that have been used to analyze the quality of science instructional materials; 2) a national Summit conference of science education leaders who are identifying, specifying, and building consensus around the criteria to be included in any tools or processes for analyzing the quality of these materials; and 3) the production and dissemination of a set of Guidelines that developers of such evaluation tools and processes can use to ensure that they include criteria for assessing alignment of materials with the NGSS, criteria that represent a consensus among leading science educators. The Guidelines produced are being disseminated throughout the science education community by the key leaders participating in this project. The Guidelines will inform development of tools and processes to consistently evaluate alignment of materials with the intent of the NGSS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Instructional materials are an important and persistent resource in US classrooms, a resource that can and should support the vision of science education set forth in the Framework for K–12 Science Education (National Research Council, 2012) and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS; Lead States, 2013). The National Research Council recognized the importance of instructional materials in its publication Monitoring Progress to Successful K-12 STEM Education (Monitoring Progress; 2013). Specifically, Indicator 4 in Monitoring Progress calls to measure the “Adoption of instructional materials in grades K-12 that embody the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics and A Framework for K-12 Science Education” (p. 19). This project addressed Indicator 4 through its primary product, Guidelines for the Evaluation of Instructional Materials in Science, available at http://guidelinesummit.bscs.org/.

The Guidelines document was developed collaboratively by key leaders in science education. It represents consensus among these leaders regarding the critical criteria for evaluating materials and valid, reliable tools and processes for conducting such an evaluation. The Evaluative Criteria included in the Guidelines embody the vision of what high quality instructional materials should look like in light of the Framework and the NGSS. The Guidelines describe the purpose of each criterion and provide the rationale for including each. The rationale is followed by specific indicators to consider when evaluating materials each criterion. The criteria are organized into four broad categories:

  1. Instructional materials support NGSS-driven learning goals.
  2. Instructional materials provide coherence across the three dimensions of the NGSS: disciplinary core ideas, science and engineering practices, and crosscutting concepts.
  3. Instructional materials support science learning experiences that promote three-dimensional learning.
  4. Instructional materials provide ways to monitor student learning across the three dimensions.

The Guidelines document also describes nine features that should characterize systems for evaluating instructional materials. There are three guidelines each for general characteristics of the evaluation system, tools included in the system, and processes used in applying the tools.

The activities in this project promoted collaboration and consensus among science education leaders regarding the criteria and methods of measurement used to evaluate widely used instructional materials, a key indicator needed to monitor national progress in science education. The Guidelines are being disseminated throughout the science education community by the key leaders who participated in this project. They are currently guiding the development of tools and processes that will consistently identify high quality science instructional materials and evaluate the extent to which they embody the NGSS.
